714799f-a.text:
East 90th Street, north side, east from Lexington to Third Aves., showing an 8-story structure, No. 159-163, occupied until recently by the Manhattan General Hospital. In the early part of 1937 they moved into the vacated building, on the west side of Second Ave., between East 17th and 18th Streets, that was formerly the Lying-In Hospital; the latter in turn having become associated in New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College Center.
August 13, 1937.
George D. Chinn.
According to the New York Times of January 3, 1938, Nos. 149 to 157 East 90th Street will be demolished and the site improved by a 6-story structure. This site comprises the buildings between the Hospital and the two corner buildings seen in the foreground.

721080f-a.text:
1360 to 1354 Lexington Ave., (right to left) at, adjoining and
south of the S.W. corner of East 90th Street.
August 13, 1937.
George D. Chinn.

721081f-a.text:
1361-65 and 1377-79 Lexington Ave., east side, north from E. 90th to 91st Streets. Also shown (right) are No's. 145 and 147 East 90th Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Lexington Avenue. The corner house bears No. 145 East 90th Street and 1361-1365 Lexington
Avenue.
August 13, 1937.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

721086f-a.text:
1396 to 1364 Lexington Avenue, west side, south from E. 92nd to 90th Streets. The 7 story apartment house, shown on the right, is the Mildred and bears Nos. 1396-92 Lexington Avenue and 140 E. 92nd
Street.
August 13, 1937.
Cift of Geo. D. Chinn.
